This is what i guess i was trying to get at from the beginning, instead of
very long intellectual answers that are too complicated for my tiny brain.
Java does allow reflection to get to private methods. Ideally, my design
would be such that private methods wouldn't do the real work (maybe they
need to be filtered out into another class), but i don't want to start
another
debate.
Why not just have an option to allow testing private methods, and those like
me who use the excuse "in the interests of time" for our bad design could put

functionality into private methods that needs to be tested...

John Goodsen wrote:

> > On Fri, Mar 29, 2002 at 01:37:41PM -0600, David Stagner wrote:
> > > If you want to test private methods directly, you must run your
> > > tests as inner classes.
> >
> > Not entirely true.
> >
> > Since JDK1.2, reflection can be used to circumvent the
> > protected/private/package private access control mechanism; provided
> > that the client wishing to do so has a
> > ReflectPermission("suppressAccessChecks") permission.
> >
> > See java.lang.class.getDeclaredMethods(),
> >     java.lang.reflect.Method and
> >     java.lang.reflect.AccessibleObject.
>
> I used to test private methods.  Now I ask myself, why I am
> trying to get into the guts of the implementation and not
> just testing from the public interface.  Using Design
> By Contract to spec out the public interface and guide
> what tests need to be written helps me do just that.
> Whenever I find myself wanting to access private parts
> in a test case, I step back and rethink why I want to
> do it... Usually it is because I am not writing my
> test first, I am writing after the fact, with knowledge
> of the implementation ...  I slap myself and get back
> into writing the tests first and all is better.
